title: Quiz 1: NCK Paper One - September 2017
description: Examination for Admission to the Register of Community Health Nurses (Basic) - September 2017. Covers Medical-Surgical, Pediatric, and Community Health Nursing concepts.

questions.question: The following are the membranes that cover the brain from inside out:
questions.explanation: The meninges are arranged from the brain surface outward as: 1. Pia mater (innermost, adheres to brain). 2. Arachnoid mater (middle, web-like). 3. Dura mater (outermost, tough/fibrous). Therefore, 'inside out' is Pia -> Arachnoid -> Dura.
questions.hint: Start with the membrane that adheres directly to the brain surface.

questions.question: Food poisoning is often caused by:
questions.explanation: Salmonella species are classic causes of bacterial food poisoning (Salmonellosis), often associated with contaminated poultry, eggs, and dairy.
questions.hint: Think of the bacteria commonly associated with undercooked poultry or eggs.

questions.question: Which observations are noted on a patient with underwater seal drainage?

options.text: Vital signs, patient connections, colour of draining.
Vital signs, colour of drainage, amount of drainage.
Vital signs, patient understanding of the procedure, amount of drainage.
Vital signs, patient understanding of the procedure, cyanosis.

questions.explanation: Priority observations for Underwater Seal Drainage (UWSD) include: 1. Patient Status (Vital signs). 2. System Integrity (Checking patient connections to ensure an airtight seal). 3. Drainage (Color and amount). Checking connections is a fundamental safety check.
questions.hint: The integrity of the system's seal is critical.

questions.question: Fractures of the base of the skull will manifest with:

options.text: Hemorrhage from the nose, the pharynx or the ears.
Cerebrospinal fluid leakage from the ears.

questions.explanation: Otorrhea (leakage of CSF from the ear) is a classic sign of a basilar skull fracture. Other signs include Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis) and Battle's sign (mastoid ecchymosis).
questions.hint: Look for signs of dural tearing allowing fluid escape.

questions.question: Which cranial nerve is involved when the patient presents with facial pain, diminished corneal reflex and chewing dysfunction?
questions.explanation: The Trigeminal Nerve (CN V) has three branches and is responsible for: 1. Sensation: Facial sensation/pain. 2. Reflex: Corneal reflex (sensory arm). 3. Motor: Muscles of mastication (chewing).
questions.hint: This nerve has three branches (Tri-).

questions.question: After liver biopsy the patient should be nursed:

options.text: Flat on his back for 6 – 8 hours.
On the right side with a small pillow on the site for 4 – 6 hours.
On the left side with a small pillow on the site for 4 – 6 hours.

questions.explanation: The liver is located on the right side. Lying on the right side (operative side) applies direct pressure to the biopsy site against the abdominal wall/pillow, which helps prevent bleeding (hemostasis).
questions.hint: Positioning is used to apply pressure to the biopsy site.

questions.question: In the management of impetigo, antibiotics are used to:
questions.explanation: Impetigo is highly contagious. Antibiotic treatment eliminates the bacteria (Staph/Strep), thereby healing the lesion and rapidly making the patient non-contagious, preventing spread to others.
questions.hint: Impetigo spreads very easily through contact.

questions.question: Match the type of gastric procedure with its correct description:

pairs.right: Removal of the lower portion of the stomach and portion of duodenum
Incision made to enlarge the outlet and relax pyloric muscle

questions.explanation: Vagotomy involves severing the vagus nerve to reduce gastric acid secretion. Antrectomy is the removal of the antrum (lower stomach). Pyloroplasty enlarges the pylorus.
questions.hint: Vagotomy relates to a nerve; Antrectomy relates to the 'antrum' of the stomach.

questions.question: One major immediate complication following Cystoscopy procedure is:
questions.explanation: Burning, mild hematuria, and frequency are expected side effects due to urethral irritation. Urine retention (due to edema or clot obstruction) is a significant complication requiring intervention.
questions.hint: Distinguish between expected side effects and complications requiring intervention.

questions.question: Following renal trauma, in order to prioritize care, the nurse monitors the patient for:

options.text: Signs of infection, urine output, heamaturia.
Heamaturia, urine output, signs of infection.
Urine output, signs of infection, heamaturia.
Urine output, heamaturia, signs of infection.

questions.explanation: Priorities are ABCs (Shock) -> Function -> Infection. Monitoring Urine Output (Systemic perfusion/shock) and Hematuria (Injury extent) takes precedence over Infection, which is a later complication.
questions.hint: Follow the hierarchy: Shock/Hemorrhage -> Function -> Infection.

questions.question: Buck's extension traction is indicated for fractures of:
questions.explanation: Buck's traction is skin traction applied to the lower limb (tibia area), typically used to reduce muscle spasms and immobilize Hip or Femur fractures. Among the choices, Tibia is the only lower limb bone listed.
questions.hint: Buck's traction is applied to the lower leg.

questions.question: Osteoarthritis may be defined as:
questions.explanation: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of articular cartilage ('wear and tear').
questions.hint: Think 'wear and tear' rather than inflammation.

questions.question: The main reason superficial burns are more painful is that:

options.text: Oedema causes pressure on the blood vessels.
Superficial nerves become hypersensitive due to impaired circulation.
Sensory nerve ending have been exposed.
The motor nerve ending have been destroyed.

questions.explanation: In superficial partial-thickness burns (2nd degree), the nerve endings are exposed and irritated by air and touch, causing severe pain. In deep burns, nerves are destroyed.
questions.hint: Why does a paper cut hurt more than a deep cut sometimes? Think about nerve exposure.

questions.question: Long term complications of burns include:

options.text: Scaring, contracture, deep venous thrombosis, infection.
Scaring, contracture, deep venous thrombosis, hypovolumia.

questions.explanation: Hypovolemia and Infection are acute/intermediate complications. Scarring, Contractures, Disfigurement, and Psychological trauma are chronic/long-term sequelae.
questions.hint: Identify the complications that persist for months or years after the injury.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding gynecological procedures are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Culdoscopy is a procedure used to investigate infertility or ectopic pregnancy.
Colposcopy is a procedure used to visualize fallopian tubes.
Culdoscopy visualizes the pelvic organs via the vaginal wall.
Colposcopy is used to examine the cervix, vagina, and vulva.

questions.explanation: Culdoscopy allows visualization of pelvic organs behind the uterus to check for ectopic pregnancy. Colposcopy examines the cervix/vagina, NOT the fallopian tubes (which are viewed via laparoscopy or salpingoscopy).
questions.hint: Colposcopy looks at the 'Colpo-' (vagina/cervix).

questions.question: The main long-term complication following radical mastectomy is:
questions.explanation: Radical mastectomy involves removal of axillary lymph nodes. This disrupts lymph drainage, leading to chronic accumulation of lymph fluid in the arm (Lymphedema).
questions.hint: Removal of lymph nodes disrupts fluid drainage.

questions.question: The following are sequential steps undertaken by the nurse if anaphylactic reaction occurs during management of status asthmaticus:

options.text: Establish airway, give epinephrine, apply a tourniquet above injection site.
Establish airway, apply tourniquet above injection site, give epinephrine.
Give epinephrine, establish airway, apply tourniquet above injection site.
Apply tourniquet above injection site, establish airway, give epinephrine.

questions.explanation: 1. Airway (Priority due to laryngeal edema risk). 2. Epinephrine (Definitive antidote). 3. Tourniquet (Proximal to site to slow absorption, if applicable).
questions.hint: ABCs: Airway is always the first priority.

questions.question: Following management of nose fractures, swelling can be reduced by:
questions.explanation: Ice packs cause vasoconstriction, which reduces bleeding, edema (swelling), and pain immediately after injury. Warm compresses would increase swelling.
questions.hint: Vasoconstriction reduces swelling.

questions.question: Uveitis is the inflammation of the:
questions.explanation: The Uvea (Uveal tract) consists of three parts: the Iris, Ciliary body, and Choroid.
questions.hint: Recall the three components of the uveal tract.

questions.question: Terminal cleaning in the operating theatre refers to:

options.text: Cleaning and preparation of operating theatre between cases.
Cleaning and disinfecting operating theatre when a patient dies.
Cleaning and disinfecting of theatre at the completion of the days schedule.
Preparation of the operating theatre before arrival of the next patient.

questions.explanation: Terminal cleaning is the thorough, deep cleaning and disinfection performed at the end of the day's operating list (or weekly), ensuring all surfaces and equipment are sanitized for the next day.
questions.hint: It happens at the 'end' (terminal) of the schedule.

questions.question: Place the first four steps of the nursing process in the correct order:
questions.explanation: 1. Assessment: Data collection. 2. Diagnosis: Identifying problems. 3. Planning: Setting goals/interventions. 4. Implementation: Action. (5. Evaluation).
questions.hint: Remember ADPIE.

questions.question: Select the correct characteristics of Benzyl Penicillin:

options.text: It acts by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis (Bactericidal).
Common side effects include hypersensitivity reactions and GI upset.
It should be administered via deep Intramuscular (IM) injection.

questions.explanation: Benzyl Penicillin is a Beta-lactam antibiotic that kills bacteria by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. Key nursing considerations include checking for allergies and administering deep IM to reduce pain.
questions.hint: Think about the drug class and safety precautions for penicillin.

questions.question: Which interventions are appropriate for managing a patient with Ascites?

options.text: Place in Semi-Fowler's position to facilitate breathing.
Enforce strict fluid restriction and low-sodium diet.
Measure abdominal girth and record daily weights.

questions.explanation: Ascites causes pressure on the diaphragm, so upright positioning helps. Fluid/Salt restriction prevents further retention. Daily weights and girth measurements track fluid status.
questions.hint: Focus on relieving pressure and preventing fluid accumulation.

questions.question: Select the four types of Jaundice:
questions.explanation: The main types classify where the problem lies: Pre-hepatic (Hemolysis), Hepatic (Liver damage), Post-hepatic (Obstruction), plus Neonatal jaundice due to immaturity.
questions.hint: Think about the pathway of bilirubin metabolism.

questions.question: Match the hospital waste bin color with the correct waste type:

richContent.content:
Bin ColorExample Content
BlackPaper wrappers
YellowSoiled cotton/dressings
Safety BoxNeedles/Blades

questions.explanation: Black for general, Yellow for infectious/clinical, Red for highly infectious/plastics, Safety box for sharps.
questions.hint: Yellow implies caution/infection; Safety boxes are for dangerous sharp items.

questions.question: What health messages regarding exercise are appropriate for a diabetic patient?

options.text: Inspect feet for injuries immediately after exercise.

questions.explanation: Diabetics must protect feet (neuropathy), prevent hypoglycemia (snacks), and exercise when blood sugar is stable (after meals), not when insulin is peaking (risk of hypo).
questions.hint: Safety focuses on foot care and preventing hypoglycemia.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical manifestations of pleural effusion?

options.text: Increased breath sounds over affected area
Decreased chest expansion on affected side

questions.explanation: Fluid in the pleural space reduces lung expansion (decreased movement), dampens sound (decreased breath sounds), and creates a dull thud on percussion (dullness).
questions.hint: Fluid blocks sound and prevents expansion.

questions.question: Identify the possible sites for an ectopic pregnancy:
questions.explanation: Ectopic pregnancy can occur anywhere outside the uterus. Common sites are the Fallopian tube (Ampulla, Isthmus, Fimbriae), Ovary, Cervix, or Abdomen. Uterine cavity is the normal site.
questions.hint: Anywhere outside the main uterine cavity.

questions.question: Case Study: Mrs. Jay (35y) is admitted with status asthmaticus. Which nursing interventions are appropriate during the acute attack?

richContent.content:
Case: Status Asthmaticus

Mrs. Jay, 35, is admitted with severe respiratory distress, wheezing, and anxiety. Diagnosis: Status Asthmaticus.

options.text: Administer humidified oxygen to maintain SpO2 >90%.
Administer sedatives to calm the patient.

questions.explanation: Priorities: Airway/Breathing (Position, O2, Bronchodilators). IV Steroids reduce inflammation. Sedatives are contraindicated as they can depress respiratory drive.
questions.hint: Focus on opening airways and reducing inflammation. Avoid respiratory depressants.

questions.question: Case Study: Mrs. X (48y) has a new colostomy following colon cancer surgery. Which management steps are correct?

richContent.content:
Case: New Colostomy

Mrs. X has undergone surgery for colon cancer and now has a stoma.

options.text: Inspect stoma frequently; it should be beefy red/pink and moist.
A dusky or black stoma is normal in the first 24 hours.
Clean skin around stoma with warm water and dry thoroughly.
Empty the bag when it is completely full.
Encourage the patient to look at and touch the stoma.

questions.explanation: Stomas must be red/pink (dusky=necrosis/emergency). Skin care prevents breakdown. Bags should be emptied when 1/3 to 1/2 full to prevent leakage. Psychological support involves encouraging interaction with the stoma.
questions.hint: Stoma color indicates blood supply. Bag weight affects seal integrity.
